body:
The error message is an S3 error message.  Presumably ACD is based on S3, but I don't think it should be exposing S3 error messages, which makes me wonder whether this is an ACD problem.

I'm pretty sure the web gui uses a different API to the one used by rclone since it can, for example, delete files permanently which the published API can't.

Tomorrow I'll try a 10 GB file myself and see what happens.

Any thoughts @klauspost  ?

@ncw good point about the web gui using a different method to access ACD.

Tested the download with another tool, acd_cli, and it worked.

```
$ docker-acdcli -v dl /Videos/Raw/footage.m2ts 
15-11-09 07:34:46.087 [INFO] [acd_cli] - Plugin leaf classes: TestPlugin
15-11-09 07:34:46.087 [INFO] [acd_cli] - TestPlugin attached.
15-11-09 07:34:46.087 [INFO] [acdcli.api.client] - Initializing ACD with path "/home/user/.cache/acd_cli".
15-11-09 07:34:46.087 [INFO] [acdcli.api.oauth] - AppspotOAuthHandler initialized
15-11-09 07:34:46.088 [INFO] [acdcli.cache.db] - Initializing cache with path "/home/user/.cache/acd_cli".
15-11-09 07:34:46.302 [INFO] [acdcli.cache.db] - Cache is initialized.
15-11-09 07:34:46.305 [INFO] [acdcli.cache.db] - DB schema version is 1.
15-11-09 07:34:46.327 [INFO] [acd_cli] - Last sync at 2015-11-09 07:30:24.625790.
15-11-09 07:34:46.413 [INFO] [acd_cli] - Resolved "/Videos/Raw/footage.m2ts" to "nDMe3qnFM1OgAiUXNpMFoq"
15-11-09 07:34:46.416 [INFO] [acdcli.utils.threading] - 1 jobs in queue.
15-11-09 07:34:46.421 [INFO] [acd_cli] - Downloading "footage.m2ts"
15-11-09 07:34:46.422 [INFO] [acdcli.api.backoff_req] - GET "https://content-na.drive.amazonaws.com/cdproxy/nodes/nDMe3qnFM1OgAiUXNpMFoq/content"
15-11-09 07:34:46.428 [INFO] [requests.packages.urllib3.connectionpool] - Starting new HTTPS connection (1): content-na.drive.amazonaws.com
15-11-09 07:34:47.024 [INFO] [requests.packages.urllib3.connectionpool] - Starting new HTTPS connection (1): cd-na-prod-content.s3.amazonaws.com

... download is starting ...
```

Interestingly, there is a [resolved issue](https://github.com/yadayada/acd_cli/issues/8) for acd_cli concering files larger than 10GB, with Amazon support acknowledging that there was an issue with downloading larger files. The current ["official" maximum file size](https://forums.developer.amazon.com/forums/thread.jspa?threadID=4610) for ACD is 50GB btw.

Anyhow, what's interesting is that the download of said file works with acd_cli. They have a [git commit](https://github.com/yadayada/acd_cli/commit/8cd8bd950b167160a42c98781153dc4bf3731a72) designated as a workaround for large files involving chunked/ranged downloads (in content.py).
Unfortunately I can't upload a >10GB file as I only have 10GB of quota :-(

@ncw no problem. I used the --dump-bodies flag to get more information where things might wrong. The 11GB file was uploaded with Cloud Drive Desktop. Here is the associated JSON-encoded metadata (with some IDs removed for privacy reasons): ``` {"data":[{"eTagResponse":"cJwi8ziqd8I","id":"","kind":"FILE","version":3,"labels":[],"contentProperties":{"extension":"m2ts","size":11956715520,"contentType":"application/octet-stream","version":1,"md5":"28909758cf5ef75fc8cfc2a58b2b9317"},"createdDate":"2015-08-30T12:53:49.238Z","createdBy":"CloudDriveDesktop","restricted":false,"modifiedDate":"2015-08-30T22:14:45.746Z","name":"footage.m2ts","isShared":false,"parents":[""],"status":"AVAILABLE"}],"count":1} ``` In comparison, here the metadata from another file that was uploaded through a third party app using the ACD api: ``` {"data":[{"eTagResponse":"VaSg_YDsTa4","id":"","kind":"FILE","version":2,"labels":[],"contentProperties":{"extension":"cmuprops","size":80140,"contentType":"application/xml","version":1,"md5":"0fbab9ecbbdc9ade6d07712348600eeb"},"createdDate":"2015-08-29T10:17:02.889Z","createdBy":"SyncBackPro","restricted":false,"modifiedDate":"2015-08-29T10:17:03.201Z","name":"footage.cmuprops","isShared":false,"parents":[""],"status":"AVAILABLE"}],"count":1} ``` Notice how it shows different fields for "version"? Anyhow, in the next step, when rclone requests the 11GB file with GET /cdproxy/nodes//content HTTP/1.1, it receives the following response. ``` 2015/11/09 16:38:11 >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 2015/11/09 16:38:12 <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< 2015/11/09 16:38:12 HTTP RESPONSE 2015/11/09 16:38:12 HTTP/1.1 302 Found Connection: keep-alive Date: Mon, 09 Nov 2015 15:38:12 GMT Location: https://cd-na-prod-content.s3.amazonaws.com/idremoved?response-content-disposition=attachment%3B%20filename%3D%22footage.m2ts%22&response-content-type=application%2Foctet-stream&x-amz-security-token=&AWSAccessKeyId=&Expires=1447083792&Signature= Server: Amazon-Cloud-Drive X-Amzn-Requestid: Content-Length: 0 ``` This is different from a normal response which looks like this: ``` 2015/11/09 16:42:14 >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 2015/11/09 16:42:15 <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< 2015/11/09 16:42:15 HTTP RESPONSE 2015/11/09 16:42:15 HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Length: 80140 Cache-Control: public, max-age=7200 Connection: keep-alive Content-Disposition: attachment; filename=footage.cmuprops Content-Type: application/xml Date: Mon, 09 Nov 2015 15:42:15 GMT Etag: "0fbab9ecbbdc9ade6d07712348600eeb" Server: Amazon-Cloud-Drive X-Amzn-Requestid: ``` So when rclone receives the 302 redirect in the case of the 11GB file, it makes another request query that looks like this: ``` GET /?response-content-disposition=attachment%3B%20filename%3D%22footage.m2ts%22&response-content-type=application%2Foctet-stream&x-amz-security-token=&AWSAccessKeyId=&Expires=1447083792&Signature= HTTP/1.1 Host: cd-na-prod-content.s3.amazonaws.com ``` Which then causes the HTTP/1.1 400 Bad Request error that we've already seen in my first post: ``` InvalidArgumentOnly one auth mechanism allowed; only the X-Amz-Algorithm query parameter, Signature query string parameter or the Authorization header should be specifiedAuthorizationremovedrequestidhostid ``` Perhaps, if rclone was to strip out the query strings containing the S3-related information that it receives in the 302 redirect response, the error might disappear? If you need the full output, I can send it to you via Email.

Excellent detective work - the error message now makes sense.

The redirected request is going to S3 - `cd-na-prod-content.s3.amazonaws.com`

S3 is getting auth info from the URL but rclone will be adding an `Authorization:` line with the oauth credentials for ACD also which is confusing it.

The best way to fix this is for rclone not to put in the `Authorization:` header if it detects that it has been redirected to S3, or maybe if there is `Signature` in the URL string.

I don't think stripping the query strings will work as then it will be sending ACD auth to S3.

I'm not quite sure how to code this though! Perhaps putting in a redirect policy which stops redirecting when it gets a 301 with a `Signature` in the URL.  The 301 would be returned to the client and it could then do another fetch using a non oauth client...  It might be that this can be fixed in the oauth transport. Needs a bit of thought.

I am glad if I could help. Apparantly the version attribute in the node's metadata is incremented each time the content or metadata is modified; so it's unrelated here.

I did a quick look at how acd_cli processes the request (using the Python Requests library), and practically, it works because it drops the Authorization header (as you suggested) in the redirected request while keeping the S3 query string parameters intact.

In fact, I couldn't see any logic in the code that would participate the redirect. Rather, it's the Python Requests library that by default always drops authorization headers when you get redirected off-host. ;) See [here](https://github.com/kennethreitz/requests/blob/6c2d09dc2f3b9f2035abf71ad7df3f52449a1e08/requests/sessions.py):

```
def rebuild_auth(self, prepared_request, response):
        """
        When being redirected we may want to strip authentication from the
        request to avoid leaking credentials. This method intelligently removes
        and reapplies authentication where possible to avoid credential loss.
        """
        headers = prepared_request.headers
        url = prepared_request.url

        if 'Authorization' in headers:
            # If we get redirected to a new host, we should strip out any
            # authentication headers.
            original_parsed = urlparse(response.request.url)
            redirect_parsed = urlparse(url)

            if (original_parsed.hostname != redirect_parsed.hostname):
                del headers['Authorization']

        # .netrc might have more auth for us on our new host.
        new_auth = get_netrc_auth(url) if self.trust_env else None
        if new_auth is not None:
            prepared_request.prepare_auth(new_auth)

        return
```

If you are interested, there is some discussion related to this [over here](https://github.com/kennethreitz/requests/issues/627).
That link is very interesting.  It makes me wonder if the current behaviour is a bug in the [oauth library](https://github.com/golang/oauth2).  Will investigate further.

Yes, the oauth library implements the http.RoundTripper interface in which they set the authentication header for [any http request](https://github.com/golang/oauth2/blob/038cb4adce85ed41e285c2e7cc6221a92bfa44aa/transport.go#L46).

I don't know if this can be considered a bug. Probably, if you assume that you ought to remove authentication headers when redirecting to a new host (RFC specs aren't clear about it, but consensus seems that you should remove them to prevent information leakage).

issue.title: Files greater than 50GB are attempted when uploading to Amazon Cloud Drive

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
When syncing up to ACD, files larger than 50GB (the limit) are attempted and then fail at completion (after some hours of copying). I think that they should be rejected with an error when discovered in the sync. Each time the sync is attempted the upload is attempted again.

And, thanks for a great utility, I've moved TBs with this tool already!

issue.title: on ACD. large files give 504 error. The files appears to be on ACD. Rclone redoes the upload.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
on ACD. large files give 504 error. The files appears to be on ACD. Rclone redoes the upload.

This seems to happen roughly 100% of the time on files of size 10-50GB that I've tested it on so far.
The end result of some files is that they upload fine the first try. Some files will 504 three times and then rclone will exit (it only retries the command three times).... after the third time the file is just on ACD... as far as I can tell all three uploads worked perfectly. While the error message appears almost always on these files the unneeded repetitions only happens maybe 10-20% of the time? or looking over my test files it seems the unneeded repetitions happen always on files greater than 31gb and on files 10-31gb the error message appears but then in the second round the check realizes it doesn't need to repeat and so doesn't.

I'm on ethernet not wireless which is why I didn't just post in this thread: https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/183

edit: here's a quote of an exact error of this type:
2015/12/24 20:59:52 gigatribe stuff 1.5.7z.003: Failed to copy: HTTP code 504: "
504 GATEWAY_TIMEOUT", no response body

body: Any news? This is still an issue with ACD during download of files larger than 10GB.
Don't worry we haven't forgotten about it! We've been thinking about it
Glad to hear that. Is there an ETA?
I have the same problem, anything good NEWS?

Hmm, I just had another look at this.  The error message from amazon has changed giving a 400 error message immediately.

This means that unfortunately I can't fix this in rclone.  It does mean that amazon is working on large file handling though which is good, but at the moment It looks like that files bigger than 10GB can't be downloaded by any means (including by the web site - which was working).

There is a [forum thread](https://www.amazon.com/gp/help/customer/forums/ref=cs_hc_g_pg_next?ie=UTF8&forumID=Fx1SKFFP8U1B6N5&cdThread=Tx3HYABOMJUH2PE&cdPage=2&cdSort=oldest) about this too.

```
2016/01/22 13:21:46 HTTP REQUEST
2016/01/22 13:21:46 GET /cdproxy/nodes/3e4ts-snip-Aw/content HTTP/1.1
Host: content-eu.drive.amazonaws.com
User-Agent: rclone/v1.26
Accept-Encoding: gzip
```

```
2016/01/22 13:21:46 HTTP RESPONSE
2016/01/22 13:21:46 HTTP/1.1 400 Bad Request
Content-Length: 46
Connection: keep-alive
Content-Type: application/vnd.error+json
Date: Fri, 22 Jan 2016 13:20:39 GMT
Server: Amazon-Cloud-Drive
X-Amzn-Requestid: 7cd83496-snip

{"message":"Currently unsupported file size."}
```

I found a moderately definitive statement from amazon on the [developers forum](https://forums.developer.amazon.com/forums/thread.jspa?threadID=8815&tstart=0) from Sep 11, 2015 

> Currently, there's a maximum download size of 10GB, so we don't recommend allowing uploads larger than this. However, the API has no upper restriction on upload file size. The download limitation should be removed in the future. 

I should probably put this in the docs...

Just FYI you can download files larger than 10GB from their website: 
https://www.amazon.com/clouddrive

Although, you have to select each file and press download, one at a time. You cannot download folders and the speed is absolutely shit.

issue.title: Document Amazon's current position on downloading files > 10GB

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

body:
NO, it means past.
Amazon allow you to download your files!
I just download a 37GB file from Amazon cloud yesterday and finished!
I download completely with jdownloader 2 and no problem.
And try using chrome to download was fine too.(but I cancel it , afraid Internet corrupt)
If you want to confirm or test, I can send you a file link large than 10GB to try.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/help/customer/display.html?nodeId=201376660
This is for multi files download, more than 5GB or 1000 files can't be download.
But I can download one of them large than 5GB in single.

I tried downloading a 12GB file from the web interface and it failed right at the start (using chrome/linux).  It didn't give any sort of error message though I can see it made a "400 Bad request" in the javascript console, which agrees with my findings with rclone.

If you can send me a file link to test that would be very useful ( private email nick@craig-wood.com ).

I wonder if jdownloader is using a different mechanism for downloading - I'll try with it later.

I send the email to you.
jdownloader is really good at download.
I can give it one Amazon cloud file link with lots of files include, and jdownloader can download them in the same time.
I think jdownloader download 1 file a time and 10 files do 10 times request.(Still single download)

@victor21813 thanks for the links - I've done some investigation and I think the thing to do for large files on amazon cloud drive would be to request a `tempLink` and download them without auth from that link.

[Getting file metadata section](https://developer.amazon.com/public/apis/experience/cloud-drive/content/nodes)

That should be a direct download from S3 which doesn't have any limits.

I haven't tried it yet though - I'll let you know how it goes!
